block.p: As an Economic Partner, Iran Builds Its Role in Iraq While the Bush administration works to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, the economies of both countries, the largest Shiite-majority countries in the world, are becoming closely integrated, with Iranian goods flooding Iraqi markets and Iraqi cities looking to Iran for basic services.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed that Iran would never dismantle its nuclear program, even in the face of a new round of sanctions from the United Nations Security Council.

An Elaborate Escape in Basra Ten Iraqis being held in a British military detention center in Basra carried out an audacious escape plan over the past several days: they switched places with visitors, British authorities said. A7

A British soldier who died four years ago after an American military pilot in Iraq opened fire on his convoy was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled. The American military already concluded that the shooting was an understandable mistake.

Gaza Gunmen Fire on U.N. Car In what was apparently a kidnapping attempt, Palestinian gunmen fired 14 bullets into the armored car of the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency. No one was hurt.

White House Delays Action In Inquiry on Attorneys The White House has delayed until next week a decision on whether to release additional documents and to allow top aides to President Bush, including Karl Rove, the chief political adviser, to testify in a Congressional inquiry into the dismissal of federal prosecutors.

Ex-C.I.A. Agent Speaks Out Valerie Wilson finally spoke, testifying to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, after almost four years at the silent center of a political scandal that touched Washington's most rarefied circles of government and news media.

Battle Over Casino Licenses The legal battle over appeals filed by four companies that lost out in the recent round of bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania could cost the state hundreds of millions of dollars in gambling tax revenue and delay property tax relief.
Three Divers Killed in Florida Three New Jersey men, all advanced certified divers, were killed off the Florida Keys while scuba diving and embarking on a risky exploration of a sunken vessel.

Employees Lose Appeal on Pill The Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees by excluding birth-control pills from its health-insurance coverage, according to a federal appellate panel in St. Louis.

Three Detectives Indicted In Killing of Unarmed Man A Queens grand jury voted to indict three New York police detectives in the killing of an unarmed black man who died in a hail of 50 police bullets. Two of the detectives were charged with second-degree manslaughter and a third with the lesser charge of reckless endangerment. A1

Messy Storm Hits Region A harsh winter storm marked by a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain descended on the Northeast, burying parts of the region in damp snow, halting air traffic at many airports and stranding thousands of travelers. B1

Mortgage Market Crisis Several large mortgage companies have stopped accepting new loans, and others have tightened lending standards, as hundreds of thousands of families who bought houses in the last two years are being expelled back into rental housing.
Senior Democrats in Congress have begun drafting legislation to curtail predatory lending practices. C1
Editorials: Taming fossil fuels; trade and the home front; more rights in Egypt, not fewer; Nicholas Kulish on Shane MacGowan and the Pogues.
Bridge: B12 TV Listings: B16 Crossword: B13 Weather: A8
